utterances: And let's see if we can go now to Will(ph), and Will is calling us from Ohio.
Where's about in Ohio are you, Will?
I'm actually, I'm on my way back to Cleveland.
I should be about - about 45 minutes away from Cleveland.
About 45 minutes away from Cleveland.
So just about...
Right.
Just about back home.
Just about back home.
And what was your - what was your experience like in Washington?
Well, it was great.
We found just the positivity of people was - it was just incredible.
We actually had tickets to the event.
And as we got in, it just turned into this totally chaotic situation where no one could move.
Everyone was packed, shoulder to shoulder and we ended up kind of going over the fence.
The ticket area, the logistics kind of messed up.

But the amount of positivity and people just like willing to help each other out whether was a step down, just making sure that everyone else with safe amidst the kind of chaos and disorder of the event was just, it was touching.
There were also we mentioned no arrests, but also, there were no serious injuries yesterday.

There was woman who fell onto the tracks of a metro station, subway station, and there was a volunteer there who had been trained the day before as to what to do and told her to crawl under the lip of the platform, and she was, I'm sure, quite frightened, but actually safe, just minor injuries.
So no injuries yesterday, either.
Well, I didn't see anything that was - anyone was in trouble.
I did hear about the person that fell onto the tracks, but in terms of the tightness of the event with regards to safety, it was impressive.
But there was no event that I heard of the whole time I was there.
So everybody good spirited and you had a great time?
Absolutely.
All right.
Absolutely.
And your car heater is working perfectly?
It's working well.
All right.
Will, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Drive safely, please.
This is from Quinn(ph) in Alexandria, Virginia.
I was a silver ticket holder yesterday, and I am furious that we have been blamed for rushing the barriers and causing a disturbance.
We did no such thing.
We stood in the cold for hours within sight of the silver ticket holder gate and watched as unticketed people streamed into the space set aside for ticket holders.
We walked over trampled police tape toward the area we thought was reserved for us only to find that there was no more room for ticket holders.
There simply weren't enough police officers to keep the crowd from pushing into secure areas.
Security was non-existent.
I spent more than 10 hours total in the cold to get my ticket only to end up at a sushi bar on Capitol Hill watching Roberts botch the oath of office on TV.
Hi.
Yes, my husband and I took our 14-year-old twin daughters.
We drove up from Charlotte on Friday night and spent all day Saturday, Sunday and Monday there.
And where did you stay in Washington?
Initially we stayed out at Tyson's Corner because we couldn't get reservations in close enough.
When we had originally made the reservations, we had only made them for Monday and Tuesday at - in Crystal City.
I see.
So, then you came in from the hotel from Virginia?
We got up at 4 o'clock in the morning, and we rode the metro in with thousands of other people.

We walked very quickly to a spot to the second television screen on the Mall, laid out our blankets, introduced ourselves to everyone around us, watched people climb on top of the port-o-potties to get a better view and celebrated together.
Climb on top of the port-o-potties?
Oh yes.
It was a much better view if you are higher because you could get a view of the crowd.
So people climbed on the port-o-potties to take pictures for everyone.
People passing their cameras up so that everybody could get pictures from the crowds from above.
Cathy, thanks very much.
Are you safely home?
We are.
We just arrived home a few minutes ago.
OK.
Thanks very much.
I'm glad you made it.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's go now to - this is Natalie(ph), Natalie with us from Lake Oswego in Oregon.
Yes.
Hello.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm fine.
You made it back to Oregon?
I did.
Monday afternoon at around 2 p.m. on sort of a whim, I decided that if I wasn't going to be able to go to the inauguration, it'd be the biggest regret of my life.
So, I found some tickets last minute and convinced my mother and my sister to come with me, and we were out of Portland by 8:45 and in D.C.
by around 6:45 in the morning.
And then you made it down to the National Mall?
We did.
I mean - it was - we didn't even have time to even bat an eye.
We rushed over there.
The line out of Dulles International was for the bus, I think about, you know, a couple of blocks long and then to get over there, it was about half-an-hour.
And then it was just a swarm of people, and we managed to get a spot.
No tickets - in front of the Washington Monument, right in front of the jumbotron.
So all in all, I'm sure those tickets were expensive, but did you enjoy it?
Was it worth it?
We did.
It was, there was an energy there that you'd never feel anywhere else.
Despite the fact that most of us couldn't feel our feet or our hands, the second Obama came on, you just lost feeling of everything else, just so enamored with him.
Well, Natalie, I'm glad you made it back.
Thank you so much.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can get one last caller in.
This is George(ph) from Amesville in Ohio.
Hey, how are you?
Go ahead.
Hey, I was in the third street tunnel where they put all the purple ticket holders that were supposed to get in.
And as I got closer and closer and people realized they weren't going to get in, there was a little frustration, but nobody broke the line.
Everybody was nice to each other, and the coolest moment was when an African-American guy got up and led about 10,000 of us in that tunnel in singing, ""Lean On Me.
Really?
Yeah.
You could - it was like a choir.
Might have been Bill Withers.
